charts.name: Request Rate
charts.description: Latest request rate in the selected time window.

charts.name: Request Rate
charts.description: Average request rate in the selected time window.

charts.name: Top Requests
charts.description: Requests that were made most frequently in the selected time window. Click a request to drill down to related traces.

charts.name: Errors
charts.description: Latest error rate in the selected time window.

charts.name: Error (%)
charts.description: Average error rate in the selected time window.

charts.name: Top Failed Requests

sources.name: operation-fail-rate
sources.query: highpass(0, round(at('end', default(0, msum(1vw, rawsum(cs(tracing.derived.*.error.count, ${overview_filters}), operationName))))))

charts.description: Requests that failed most frequently in the selected time window. Click a request to drill down to related traces.

charts.name: Latency
charts.description: Latest latency in the selected time window.

charts.name: Latency
charts.description: Average, median and P95 latency in the selected time window.

charts.name: Slowest Requests (P95)
charts.description: Slowest requests in the selected time window. Click a request to drill down to related traces.

charts.name: Request Latency
charts.description: Request latency histogram. Click a histogram column to view traces related to that percentile.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent:
|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| ![Concourse](https://wavefront-img.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/concourse.png "Concourse") | This dashboard provides real-time visibility into **Concourse**. Concourse is an open-source continuous thing-doer. Built on the simple mechanics of resources, tasks, and jobs, Concourse presents a general approach to automation that makes it great for CI/CD. Use the drop-down menus above to select Concourse **Server**. You can find information about the metrics in the [Concourse](https://concourse-ci.org/metrics.html "_blank") documentation. |

charts.name: Job Scheduling
charts.description: Number of Concourse jobs currently being scheduled.

charts.name: Tasks Waiting
charts.description: Number of Concourse tasks currently waiting.

charts.name: Locks Held
charts.description: Database locks held.

charts.name: Running
charts.description: Number of Concourse builds currently running.

charts.name: Errored
charts.description: Total number of Concourse builds errored.

charts.name: Failed
charts.description: Total number of Concourse builds failed.

charts.name: Aborted
charts.description: Total number of Concourse builds aborted.

charts.name: Builds
charts.description: Total number of Concourse builds.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent: - **Database Connection:** If the number of database connections has increased, from the normal range, DB connections leak can be a reason for this.

charts.name: API CONNECTIONS
charts.description: Current number of concourse api database connections.

charts.name: GC CONNECTIONS
charts.description: Current number of concourse gc database connections.

charts.name: BACKEND CONNECTIONS
charts.description: Current number of concourse backend database connections.

charts.name: Queries
charts.description: Total number of Concourse database queries.

charts.name: Containers
charts.description: Number of containers per worker.

charts.name: Volumes
charts.description: Number of volumes per worker.

charts.name: Tasks
charts.description: Number of active tasks per worker.

charts.name: Workers State
charts.description: Number of workers per state as seen by the database.

charts.name: Started
charts.description: Total number of checks started.

charts.name: Errored
charts.description: Total number of checks finished with error.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent:
- **CPU Usage:** A spike in CPU usage might point to a process that is computationally heavy. Scaling app instances can relieve the immediate pressure, but you need to investigate the app to better understand and fix the root cause.
- **Memory Usage:** If the application is constantly using high memory, consider optimizing the application or increasing the memory.

charts.name: Info
charts.description: Total user and system CPU time spent in seconds.

charts.name: CPU Usage
charts.description: Total user and system CPU time spent in seconds.

charts.name: Virtual Memory
charts.description: Virtual memory size in bytes.

charts.name: FDS Free vs Open
charts.description: Maximum vs Open file descriptors.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent: - **Request Latency:** A spike in response time means your users are waiting longer. Scaling app instances can spread that workload over more resources and result in faster response times.

charts.name: Response Time
charts.description: Response time in seconds.

charts.name: Slowest API
charts.description: Top 5 slowest requests.

charts.name: 4XX Status
charts.description: Request returning 404 status code.

charts.name: 5XX Status
charts.description: Request returning 404 status code.

charts.name: Threads
charts.description: Number of OS threads created.

charts.name: Goroutines
charts.description: Number of goroutines that currently exist.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent:
- **Memory:** A consistent high (above 70 – 80%) usage of heap memory of the maximum heap that we set it to might mean a resource leak in the code. Scaling app memory can relieve the immediate pressure, but you need to find and resolve the underlying issue so that it does not occur again.
- **GC Duration:** GC pause of more than a second, or multiple pauses within a second that add to a large fraction of that second, should be avoided.

charts.name: GC Duration
charts.description: A summary of the GC invocation durations.

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent: **Note:** *This dashboard is provided by Wavefront. It's not directly editable, which lets us deploy new versions without affecting any of your customizations. If you want to make your own version, click ![pencil](https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/wavefront-img/pen-icon.png) **> Clone** and give the dashboard a new URL*.

valuesToReadableStrings.default: application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and shard="${shard}" and span.kind?="${spanKind}"
application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and shard="${shard}" and source="${source}" and span.kind?="${spanKind}"

cluster.queryValue: collect(sum(ts(~component.heartbeat, application="${application}" and service="${service}" and not "_synthetic"="true"), cluster), taggify(1, "cluster", "*"))
cluster.label: cluster

source.queryValue: collect(sum(ts(~component.heartbeat, application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and shard="${shard}" and not "_synthetic"="true"), sources), aliasSource(1, "*"))
source.label: source

valuesToReadableStrings.default: application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and shard="${shard}" and source="${source}"

spanKind.queryValue: collect(sum(ts(~component.heartbeat, application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and shard="${shard}" and not "_synthetic"="true"), "span.kind"), taggify(1, "span.kind", "*"))
spanKind.label: spanKind

shard.queryValue: collect(sum(ts(~component.heartbeat, application="${application}" and service="${service}" and cluster="${cluster}" and not "_synthetic"="true"), shard), taggify(1, "shard", "*"))
shard.label: shard
